lose.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to stop having a particular attitude, quality, ability etc, or to gradually have less of it
lose.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I’ve lost my appetite.
By the time the ambulance arrived, Douglas had lost consciousness.
The business community has lost confidence in the government.
lose confidence/interest/hope etc
Carol lost interest in ballet in her teens.
lose confidence/interest/hope etc
Try not to lose heart (=become sad and hopeless) – there are plenty of other jobs.
lose confidence/interest/hope etc
A settlement was reached in which neither side lost face.
lose face
You’re looking slim. Have you lost weight?
lose weight/height/speed etc
The plane emptied its fuel tanks as it started losing altitude.
lose weight/height/speed etc
Mr Eyer may lose the sight in one eye.
lose your sight/hearing/voice/balance etc
The tour was postponed when the lead singer lost his voice.
lose your sight/hearing/voice/balance etc
Julian lost his balance and fell.
lose your sight/hearing/voice/balance etc
This latest movie proves Altman is by no means losing his touch.
lose your touch
When he was writing, he lost all sense of time.
lose all sense of time/direction/proportion etc
We must never lose sight of the fact that man must work in harmony with nature.
lose sight of something
lose.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to not win a game, argument, election, war etc
lose.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: They played so badly they deserved to lose.
Klinger lost his seat in the election.
Arkansas just lost three games in a row.
He just can’t bear to lose an argument.
Freddie died in 1982 after losing his battle against AIDS.
The government lost by one vote.
lose (something) by 1 goal/10 votes/20 points etc
The Communist candidate lost by a whisker (=a very small amount).
lose (something) by 1 goal/10 votes/20 points etc
The Beavers have dropped only one game since losing to Oregon in January.
It was a rash decision, and it lost him the race  (=caused him to lose the race).
lose.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to become unable to find someone or something
lose.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I’ve lost the tickets for tonight’s show.
I followed her on foot, but lost her in the crowd.
It was thought the manuscript had been lost forever.
The parcel must have got lost in the post.
He lost track of her after her family moved away.
Don’t try to walk in a heavy snowstorm as you may lose sight of your vehicle.
lose.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if you lose something that is important or necessary, you then no longer have it, especially because it has been taken from you or destroyed
lose.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: David’s very upset about losing his job.
Hundreds of people lost their homes in the floods.
My family lost everything in the war.
He was over the limit and will lose his licence.
Ninety naval aircraft were lost and thirty damaged.
He’s lost a lot of blood but his life is not in danger.
If you hesitate, you may lose the opportunity to compete altogether.
He lost his leg in a motorcycle accident.
We were losing customers to cheaper rivals.
She was about to lose her husband to a younger woman.
California has lost 90% of its wetlands to development.
the mistakes which lost him his kingdom  (=caused him to lose his kingdom)
lose.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: a memorial to honor those who lost their lives in the war
lose.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if you lose a relative or friend, they die – use this when you want to avoid saying the word ‘die’
lose.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: One woman in Brooklyn lost a husband and two sons in the gang wars.
Sadly, Anna lost the baby (=her baby died before it was born).
Peter was lost at sea when his ship sank.
He lost his father to cancer  (=his father died of cancer) last year.
lose.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if you lose money, you then have less money than you had before
lose.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Creditors and investors stand to lose (=risk losing) vast sums after the company’s collapse.
A lot of people lost their shirts (=lost a lot of money) on Ferraris in the eighties.
It’s a great deal – we can’t lose!
The company is in debt after losing an estimated $30 million on its dotcom enterprise.
The stock market crash lost the banks £70 million  (=caused them to lose £70 million).
lose.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if you lose time, you do not make progress as quickly as you want to or should
lose.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Come on, there’s no time to lose (=do not waste time).
Vital minutes were lost because the ambulance took half an hour to arrive.
In 1978,29 million days were lost in industrial action.
Murdock lost no time in taking out a patent for his invention.
lose no time in doing something
lose.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if a watch, clock etc loses time, it runs too slowly and shows an earlier time than it should
lose.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if you lose someone who is chasing you, you manage to escape from them
lose.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: There’s a better chance of losing him if we take the back route.
lose.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to confuse someone when you are trying to explain something to them
lose.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Explain it again – you’ve lost me already.
lose.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to remove a part or feature of something that is not necessary or wanted
lose.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: You could lose the last paragraph to make it fit on one page.
lose.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to stop having something any more, or to have less of it
lose.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: After a boardroom battle, Dixon lost control of the company.
They lost business by not giving credit.
We started losing customers to cheaper rivals.
The big national chains were losing market share to independent one-person operations.
lose.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to have less money than you had before or to spend more money than you are receiving
lose.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: We all lost money when the firm collapsed.
The group is estimated to have lost $36 million last year.
The resulting crisis of confidence lost the bank (=caused the bank to lose) £30 million in deposits.
lose.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to fall to a lower figure or price
lose.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: In Tokyo, the Nikkei stock index lost 644.82 to close at 17,791.55.
Its shares lost 25p to 104p on the results.
lose.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to become less in value or to lose an advantage
lose.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Sterling lost ground against the euro.
When the bid failed to appear, shares lost ground.
lose.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to lose a lot of money
lose.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: When the recession came, many companies lost their shirts.
